Award.AwardTitle: Management and Operation of the National Center for Atmospheric Research, 2008-2018, and Supporting Activities

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project outcomes report represents projects that are funded by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and awarded through the National Science Foundation (NSF) Cooperative Agreement to the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR) for the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR).  The principal disciplines are meteorology and public health. The work has enhanced knowledge of a growing field of research in which meteorological data are employed to enhance understanding of disease systems.

Climate and weather influence the occurrence, distribution, and incidence of infectious diseases, particularly those caused by vector-borne or zoonotic pathogens. Thus, models based on meteorological data have helped predict when and where human cases are most likely to occur. Such knowledge aids in targeting limited prevention and control resources and may ultimately reduce the burden of diseases. Paradoxically, localities where such models could yield the greatest benefits, such as tropical regions where morbidity and mortality caused by vector-borne diseases are typically greatest, often lack high-quality in situ local meteorological data. Satellite- and model-based gridded climate datasets can be used to approximate local meteorological conditions in data-sparse regions, however, their accuracy varies. Research efforts for this award focused on how the selection of a particular dataset can influence the outcomes of disease forecasting models. The model system utilized focused on plague in the West Nile region of Uganda. The majority of recent human plague cases have been reported from East Africa and Madagascar, where meteorological observation networks are sparse and topography yields complex weather patterns. Using an ensemble of meteorological datasets and model-averaging techniques, we find that the number of suspected cases in the West Nile region is negatively associated with dry season rainfall (December-February) and positively with rainfall prior to the plague season. We demonstrate that ensembles of available meteorological datasets can be used to quantify climatic uncertainty and minimize its impacts on infectious disease models. These methods are particularly valuable in regions with sparse observational networks and high morbidity and mortality from vector-borne diseases.

The project played an integral role in training postdoctoral fellows in the variety of climate data that are available, and how to responsibly apply the data. The fellows spent time at NCAR for training in weather and climate analysis and modeling, and at CDC for training in environmental health. The joint postdoctoral appointment was designed to train scientists to bridge the gap between the meteorological community, and the health/ecology communities, which means that the results are inherently targeted at broader audiences than typical.

Climate datasets from this project have contributed to a discipline other than atmospheric science, specifically the scientific community that studies and models infectious diseases. CDC collaborators, who are health scientists, have been provided high-resolution climate datasets, which enable them to understand the climatic factors that contribute to human plague incidence and to quantitatively model them. The research results have been disseminated to the community through presentations, workshops, conferences, and publications in journals.
